emails.snippet: Dear Matthew, I hope this email finds you well. This is Vitali from the Account Helpdesk. I understand that you are being constantly prompted to enter a token from the app to maintain your WiFi
emails.body:
Dear Matthew,


I hope this email finds you well.



This is Vitali from the Account Helpdesk. I understand that you are being constantly prompted to enter a token from the app to maintain your WiFi connection.



Normally, you do not need to constantly enter a token from the app to continue using WiFi. Once you have registered your device using the authentication code, it should have instant access without needing to re-enter the code each time.



To get this sorted out, please try the following steps:



1. Forget the network: Go to your device's WiFi settings, select the network, and choose "Forget this Network." Then reconnect and enter the token one more time to establish a fresh lease.



2. Disable "Private WiFi Address" (MAC Randomization): Some devices rotate their ID for privacy. If your device changes its "identity," the system thinks it‚Äôs a new guest.



3. Check date and time: Make sure your device‚Äôs date and time are set correctly, as incorrect settings can make tokens invalid.



If the steps above do not resolve the issue, please contact your local centre team at Yorkville, who will be happy to assist with troubleshooting. You can reach them by email at Toronto.Yorkville@regus.com<mailto:Toronto.Yorkville@regus.com> or by phone at +1 416 921 5000.

Should there be anything further we can assist you with, then please do not hesitate to raise a query through the Help section of your online account.



Best regards,



Vitali F.

Account Helpdesk

iwgplc.com



New! Our virtual assistant is now live on your online account ‚Äì Just log in, use the Chat button and save time getting immediate help for any questions directly.


The information contained in this e-mail (including any attachments) is intended only for the personal
and confidential use of the recipient(s) named above. If you are not an intended recipient of this message,
please notify the sender by replying to this message and then delete the message and any copies from
your system. Any use, dissemination, distribution, or reproduction of this message by unintended
recipients, is not authorised and may be unlawful.

emails.body:
Hey Shane!

From my understanding that 6% fee is its own fee. They operate entirely separately from Seeker, they just happen to be one by the same parent company which is why there‚Äôs an intersect.

We are choosing to not activate Tokyo just yet. We have some levers to pull on already and are sticking to the plan. This will be one to activate in the coming months.

Thanks!


Michael Bou Doumit
Director of Sales & Marketing

To: Michael Bou Doumit <michael@aspireinfusions.com>, Sy Umachandran <sy@aspireinfusions.com>
Cc: Kristin Lumsden <Kristin@aspireinfusions.com>, Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Subject: RE: Seeker Cannabis | Agreement review

Hi Michael,

Please see attached. Thanks!

For Tokyo Smoke, just to confirm for the 6% fee, would it be on top of the Seeker 8% fee? So effectively a total of 14%?

Best Regards,
Shane

From: Michael Bou Doumit <michael@aspireinfusions.com>
Sent: February 6, 2026 9:03 AM
To: Sy Umachandran <sy@aspireinfusions.com>; Shane Sequeira <shane@aspireinfusions.com>
Cc: Kristin Lumsden <Kristin@aspireinfusions.com>; Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Subject: Re: Seeker Cannabis | Agreement review

Hey Sy & Shane,

Attached is a contract for a buying group with 650 retail stores and growing across Canada with about 300+ in Ontario.

Here‚Äôs a high level breakdown:
What it is:

  *   National retail access program for independent cannabis stores

  *   No upfront fee; operates via LP partnerships

  *   Optional access to Tokyo Smoke (~60 stores) as a separate channel
Why it matters:

  *   Gives us controlled access to Ontario independents we don‚Äôt already work with

  *   Current wellness assortment is thin, creating white space for our portfolio

  *   Useful lever to drive velocity on slower-moving SKUs and build broader portfolio momentum

  *   Provides store-level sales data, improving visibility and decision-making (they process the data and package it - includes competitor data)
How we‚Äôd use it:

  *   Selectively onboard priority stores (not forced to go wide)

  *   Leverage monthly promos + email support for incremental lift

  *   Sampling and education remain in-house (no loss of brand control)
Commercial terms:

  *   Seeker Collective fee: 8% (per contract)

  *   Tokyo Smoke access: 6% fee (optional, separate)

  *   Billing: One consolidated monthly invoice paid to Seeker Collective

  *   Payment terms: Net 30

  *   Term: 180 days, auto-renewing

  *   Exit: 60 days‚Äô written notice
Big picture

  *   Low operational friction, moderate cost

  *   Primary upside is distribution access + velocity support

  *   Risk is limited; commitment is short and controllable

If you have any questions, please let me know. If we‚Äôre good to go, we‚Äôd need a signature to move forward please.

Thanks,


Michael Bou Doumit
Director of Sales & Marketing



Aspire Infusions Inc.

1200 Aerowood Drive, Unit 47, Mississauga, Ontario, CA, L4W 2S7

Email: michael@aspireinfusions.com<mailto:michael@aspireinfusions.com>

emails.snippet: Why automation fails when ownership and sequence aren't clear. Hi Matthew, Quick reminder that tomorrow, February 11 at 12:00 PM ET, I'm hosting a short Legalboards Academy session: Before You
emails.body:
Why automation fails when ownership and sequence aren‚Äôt clear.

Email

Hi Matthew,

Quick reminder that tomorrow, *February 11 at 12:00 PM ET* , I‚Äôm hosting a short Legalboards Academy session:

*Before You Automate*
The three things every law firm must fix first

Automation fails when ownership, sequence, and visibility are unclear. This session breaks down what needs to be fixed before adding anything new.

We‚Äôll cover:

‚Ä¢ why automation adds friction in real firm workflows

‚Ä¢ what needs to be clear before automating anything

‚Ä¢ how to spot hidden workflow issues early

This is not a tool demo.

emails.body:
Hey Matthew! 
Heard back from legal at TD. They insist on taking out ALL of 3.4 (a,b,c,d). And 8.2. 
At this point I think we do it and move ahead to show LL. I don‚Äôt see any other way and am guessing this comes up all the time with people like me doing CSBFP‚Ä¶.. right? Ha. 

I also have been advised to change these by franchisor:

Cap on Operating expenses: We tried to have the increases limited to that of CPI increase. Landlord would not agree to any cap. We will not get this changed
Audit right won‚Äôt happen (guessing this is 4.5?)

Almost there (I think??) ugh. Thanks for any advice or to just change this. I am really anxious to get a redline in front of LL‚Ä¶. Supposed to take possession March 1! LOL. I am cutting it close. 

Thanks and let me know received and how your schedule looks :) 
CR

In a nutshell, these are some of the initial questions we would conclusively answer once we start working.

To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>>
Subject: Questions to ask the lawyer:

Ôªø 1. Did you purchase the shares of the business or the assets?

2. What does the sale agreement say about the current employees?

Find out from the previous owner:  Did the current people that work there sign employment contracts? If so, where are the contracts?

3. Should you have the current employees sign new employment agreements? If so, what consideration should be offered (you have to give them something to get them to sign)? Keep in mind that even signing the new agreement doesn't mean they start a probationary period.

Find out how long each of the employees has been there. That will tell you what kind of severance you will be responsible for if you decide to terminate them.

Kristi

Hello
We did the 70,000 franchise fee as payment for the franchise. While we where looking for a site his Growing minds became for sale and the owner of the franchise said it would be good to take Growing minds and change it to Uptown Montessori under the franchise name. I believed him and he did all the disclosure and discover on his end. The Supervisor was running the day to day operations and was told I needed to keep her and the staff they had. A week after we toke over we she demanded a big raise from 60k a year 5 days a week to almost 70k a year only working 4 days a week. She was holding all the information that ran the business and I was informed to take her deal and then find a way to get her out rhe door in a few months. From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca<mailto:matthew@levinelegal.ca>>
Sent: February 5, 2026 11:09 AM
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>>
Subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm

Hi Marjan

Good day. I have the FDD, thank you.

At a preliminary level, I have questions about how the transaction was structured, particularly in relation to the franchise agreement that was entered into and the fee that was paid. To start with, can you confirm whether a $70,000 initial franchise fee was paid, and whether you were given an explanation at the time for why the transaction was treated as a new franchise rather than a transfer or change of control?

Before I can assess whether there is a legal issue to be examined, it would be helpful to make sure I understand the situation from your perspective. In particular:

  *   What concern or issue prompted you to reach out now?

  *   Who was responsible for day-to-day management of the business at the time of the transaction, and how was that role described to you?

  *   Were you told that any individual‚Äôs continued involvement was expected or required when the deal was completed?

The reason I ask is that issues involving disclosure and transaction structure are treated differently from operational or personnel disputes, and I want to be clear on the factual background.

Once I have that context, we can discuss whether there is a legal issue worth pursuing and what the appropriate next steps might be.

Best regards



Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

emails.body:
Hi Matthew,



Have looked into the government funding and seems that anything that‚Äôs
available is for large companies and the loan amounts are aggressive.



Do you have any ideas?



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Monday, February 9, 2026 12:15 PM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project





Hey Max



When you have time, please let me know where things are at on your side and
any additional info I can informally review.



I would be confident in working on the government funding.





*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Mon, Jan 12, 2026 at 12:11‚ÄØPM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

I haven‚Äôt looked into the grant money that would be available for this but
will.



I would need some time to think about this.



Have been thinking of ways to create a product that is new and novel and
believe we have some decent idea.



You plan is great.



Give me some time to look into grant money. Please do not work on this
anymore until I get back to you.



I have enough info to push this forward for now.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Monday, January 12, 2026 12:06 PM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project



Hi Max



the patent lawyers who I know best are litigators but I do know some people
who do product development and will reach out.



I believe there may be government money available - have you looked into
that at all?



I see the next steps as:

   - *1. Legal Scoping*: counsel reviews the existing (U.S.) patent and
   scopes a design mandate focused on avoiding infringement under Canadian
   law. The scope and cost of this work will depend whether the goal is:


   - (a) to avoid infringing the existing patent (i.e., design-around), or
      - (b) to create something patentable by Mascore itself (i.e.,
      inventive and novel under the *Patent Act*).


   - *2 ‚Äì Technical Development*: The product designer works within
   specified parameters to generate technical outputs, i.e. designs, models,
   and prototypes to achieve (a) or (b)
   - *3 ‚Äì Legal Review*: counsel reviews the technical outputs and provides
   a follow-up opinion or informal assessment confirming whether the resulting
   design achieves (a) or (b)
   - *4 ‚Äì Filing & Prosecution (if pursuing a patent strategy)*: If the
   objective under Step 1 includes creating patentable subject matter, a
   separate workstream is initiated for preparation and prosecution of
   Mascore‚Äôs own patent application.

what do you think of the above?











*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Fri, Jan 9, 2026 at 12:30‚ÄØPM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

There is a US company that owns a patent on a unique deep foundation
product.



It is technically a helical pile, but it is modified and has a continuous
flight added to it that pull down concrete during installation making the
foundation much stronger. Attached is the brochure for reference.



Also attached is the Canadian and US patent.



My thoughts are:



   - The patent drawing is technically different from what they actually
   produce, although similar. The patent shows a helical shape plate with 2-3
   revolution where what they actually build is a single revolution helix
   plate.
   - We build a similar product already without a helix plate. See attached
   drawing.
   - Need to figure out a way to prove this isn‚Äôt ‚Äúnovel‚Äù
   - What type of modification can we make to it to make our own novelty?
   - An American company produces this and has plans to bring it to Canada.
   We‚Äôd like to stop this by competing with it.



I understand you earn a patent lawyer, but do you have any contacts?



Please let us know your thoughts.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Friday, January 9, 2026 11:11 AM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project



Hi Max



very interested. please send more info.



(i'm not a patent lawyer, as you know.)



happy new year





*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Thu, Jan 8, 2026 at 9:12‚ÄØAM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

HI Matthew,



Hope you are well.



I have a new project I am working on that involved patent expertise.



There is an existing product in our market that we would like to start
offering that is patented.



We would like to build a similar product without infringing or having
ourselves covered in the event of a legal action.



Is this something you can help us with?



If so, I will provide further details.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389

emails.snippet: Hi Vivien, Thank you for the helpful insights you've shared this morning, much appreciated. Apologies, Harry was unable to attend today as he is away. As mentioned on call I have looped in Matthew
emails.body:
Hi Vivien,

Thank you for the helpful insights you've shared this morning, much
appreciated.

Apologies, Harry was unable to attend today as he is away. As mentioned on
call I have looped in Matthew Levine- Legal practitioner CAMLRO of our
Canadian entity and Harry ( CEO & Founder)  in the email and shall await an
invite for the 2nd week of March 2026,  preferably 11 March  close to UK
time 3 pm.
Note- In the event one of us is unable to make it on the date we shall
update you ahead and request to reschedule.

In the interim it would be beneficial for us to get a deep dive review and
understanding of the comparative analysis ( both similarities & key
differences )-  Marble & Corsa.

Speak soon.

Thanks and regards

*Tulika Dhar *
Head of Compliance
[image: email]*tulika.d@stream.money <tulika.d@stream.money>*

C100000166, registered with FINTRAC Canada. In the UK, Stream Ventures Ltd

Digital asset services are provided by StreamDigital Sp zoo and Snowcap

emails.body:
Webinar: February 12th, 11:00 AM Eastern

Ultimate SharePoint Status Board

Register and Save Your Spot

Your organization has critical processes that need to be monitored. The trouble is that you haven’t had a good way to display key status information from SharePoint. In our next webinar, we’ll show how Infowise Ultimate Forms provides the perfect solution to easily build a SharePoint Status Board with key measurements and indicators. Choose metrics that are most important to your organization. The setup process is easy to do with no coding required. We’ll cover:

  • Pick your own key metrics
  • Display measurements in color coded boxes
  • Add interactive filters
  • Automatically roll up key data
  • Data is refreshed automatically
  • Looks great on large TVs
  • Create additional custom boards for each team
  • Show open tickets, project health, sales numbers and more

Don’t miss this opportunity to learn how to set up your own powerful SharePoint Status Board. Download the complete solution template including lists, forms, views, automation, and the full Status Board page immediately after the presentation!

The recording and a free site template will be made available to all registrants.
Unsubscribe
